content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, Given a struct `FloatWithUnits` with fields `value` and `unit` (make sure to define it!), write a `show` method for it that will concatenate the value and unit with a space like this "1.8 meters".

In Julia, you can define a custom `show` function by creating a new method for `Base.show`. Here is an example:

```julia
struct FloatWithUnits{T<:AbstractFloat}
    value::T
    unit::String
end

function Base.show(io::IO, fwu::FloatWithUnits)
    print(io, "$(fwu.value) $(fwu.unit)")
end
```
This `Base.show` function takes two arguments: an IO object (which you can think of as a "screen" where your printed output will appear) and an instance of the struct FloatWithUnits. It uses the value and unit fields to print them together in the format specified by the user.
